newsitem.title: UK: Civil research could produce new N-bombs - magazine.
newsitem.headline: Civil research could produce new N-bombs - magazine.

text.p: Scientific research being carried out in civilian, rather than military, laboratories could provide the knowledge to develop a new generation of nuclear bombs, a British defence magazine said on Wednesday.
These weapons may not be subject to treaties covering existing nuclear weapons, according to Jane's International Defense Review.

It quoted Andre Gsponer of the Independent Scientific Research Institute in Geneva as saying the weapons will be based on new research into astro-physics, nuclear physics and the physics of the elementary particles that make up matter.
Compared with present-day nuclear arsenals, tomorrow's weapons will offer big military advantages, especially when used tactically, as most will produce no sigificant radioactivity.
"They will also have political advantages since only the U.S, given its technology base, will be able to develop them," the magazine said.
It said the first type of new nuclear bombs to emerge would probably be nuclear fusion weapons.
Nuclear fusion is the process which gives the sun its energy and extremely high temperatures and pressures are needed to produce it.
Scientists have already achieved some nuclear fusion using currently available high explosives but the amount of fusion produced has not been nearly enough to be militarily useful.
This problem could be solved by new explosives currently being developed which can produce energy concentrations much greater than those produced by today's explosives.
The magazine said fusion weapons are likely to have explosive yields equivalent to those of up to 1,000 tonnes of TNT high explosive.
Nuclear fusion weapons could be triggered by lasers, which themselves would produce small thermonuclear explosions.
"U.S. nuclear scientists will study these mini thermonuclear explosions as a substitute for nuclear weapons tests," it said.
Research at the National Ignition Facility at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California is also being carried out into metallic hydrogen.
Above a certain pressure, hydrogen can be converted into a solid metallic state 30 times more explosive than conventional high explosive. This could be used in the triggers of fusion nuclear weapons.
The same function could be performed by nuclear isomers -- materials with highly excited nuclear states which can store huge amounts of energy -- also being researched at Lawrence Livermore.
